stream_context.summary: Bonus Labor Day stream focused on UV mapping/texturing an icy castle course, showing a major performance boost after getting Sauraen’s F3DEX3 microcode working, and discussing N64 optimization insights (RSP vs memory/RDP). Kaze also outlines upcoming demo/video plans, notes temporary level constraints (collision memory), and shares personal/business pressure after having a child.
stream_context.significance_reason: Kaze reports F3DEX3 working correctly with a dramatic framerate increase and reframes performance bottlenecks as RSP-limited once memory traffic is optimized—both are major technical turning points that affect the whole project. He also defines near-term deliverables (Course 1 demo) and reveals real-life monetization pressure after having a child.

findings.summary: Sauraen’s F3DEX3 microcode is now working correctly in Kaze’s build, producing a large framerate gain (around ~50 FPS in a heavy view, with optimism for stable 60 after further culling/draw-distance tuning).
findings.quote: We got F3DEX3 working correctly now… it’s basically like 50 FPS now… I’m pretty sure we can get this to stable 60.

findings.summary: Kaze concludes that once memory traffic is optimized “decently,” the RSP becomes the limiting factor (not the RDP/fillrate), and he plans a video correcting this earlier understanding.
findings.quote: We were wrong about memory traffic being so important… with X3, we found out that RSP is actually the limiting factor now—if you actually optimize your game well.

findings.summary: Even on an RSP-optimized branch, Kaze’s performance counters still show the project RSP-bottlenecked, reinforcing his claim that further gains require RSP-side optimization rather than more memory tweaks alone.
A known measurement caveat: Kaze acknowledges that enabling frame-time measurement itself reduces performance, so counters must be interpreted carefully.

Course 13 temporarily hits a hard limit: the level is running out of memory for collision triangles. Kaze says it should be resolved once they switch to a collision map; until then they may make some geometry “untouchable.”
findings.quote: We are running out of memory for collision triangles… it’s only temporary because as soon as we make a collision map, that issue will go away.

findings.summary: Lighting bug: when Mario approaches an additional light source, ambient light disappears. Kaze can’t explain it; behavior differs depending on microcode/version (works on X3, but his emulator setup loads X2, where the issue appears under certain GeoLayout lighting applications).
findings.quote: When I get close to an additional light source, the ambient light just disappears. I couldn't figure it out at all.

findings.summary: Kaze is building “room doors”/portals so that depending on where the player stands, the engine renders one room or both rooms—an explicit level-structure choice to control visibility/performance.
findings.quote: These are going to be used as room doors, so that when I'm here I render both rooms and when I'm here I just don't render the other room.

findings.summary: He plans a public-facing demo limited to Course 1 so players can try the new camera and Mario controls, implying a shift toward polishing core feel/engine features for a contained release rather than a broad “full game” demo.
findings.quote: I'm planning a demo of just Course 1… so everyone can play with the new camera and the new Mario controls.

findings.summary: Course 13’s outside area is actively being produced by Zeina; two stars are planned for outside content: an 8 Red Coins star and a hidden entrance leading to an additional sub-area/objective (described as an “8-bit”/hidden entrance).

Kaze states his visual decision-making prioritizes emotional tone over surface-level aesthetics; for this course he explicitly wants “cold and mysterious,” hence leaning into blue and subdued palettes.
findings.quote: When I'm doing visuals… I think about… emotions I want to invoke in the player. And I want this to feel cold and mysterious.

findings.summary: The course’s identity is still fluid: they brainstorm a “minty” ice-castle name and reject options like “Frosty Fortress” and “Cold Castle,” with suggestions like “Permafrost Palace” and “Paradox” variants.

Kaze observes a recurring playtesting/difficulty perception split: some viewers call segments too hard, others too easy; he cites SimpleFlips failing many times on something he considers basic, highlighting the challenge of calibrating difficulty for mixed audiences.
findings.quote: I get a lot of people saying this is too difficult, and then I get a lot of people saying this is too easy.

findings.summary: Personal pressure affects output strategy: Kaze says having a child means he needs more income, so he expects to increase YouTube output and is worried he may need to “sell out a little bit.”
findings.quote: Now that I have a child, I need to make more money… it also means I might have to sell out a little bit.

findings.summary: Kaze outlines a stacked video pipeline: an optimizations video (including making Mario 64 run worse/better), a Course 1 demo video, a Banjo-Kazooie demo video, and a technical correction video about RSP vs memory traffic.

biobak.summary: Kaze frames his own early texturing work as provisional, expecting Biobak to significantly improve visuals later—suggesting a pipeline where Kaze blocks in intent and Biobak elevates final art direction.
biobak.quote: Whatever I do is just kind of like a suggestion for Biobak and he's gonna make it look a lot better.

zeina.summary: Zeina is producing assets for Course 13’s outside area; two stars are planned around that space (including an 8 Red Coins star).

findings.summary: Sauraen’s custom F3DEX3 microcode is the enabling technology behind the new performance headroom Kaze demonstrates (and is central to the project’s new RSP-bottleneck framing).

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: We were wrong about memory traffic being so important… with X3, we found out that RSP is actually the limiting factor now—if you actually optimize your game well.
memorable_quotes.context: A project-wide optimization thesis shift: once the team optimizes memory, the bottleneck moves, changing how they should spend engineering time going forward.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: When I'm doing visuals… I think about… emotions I want to invoke in the player. And I want this to feel cold and mysterious.
memorable_quotes.context: A clear articulation of Kaze’s art-direction philosophy—useful for documentary narration about how he makes aesthetic calls.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Now that I have a child, I need to make more money… it also means I might have to sell out a little bit.
memorable_quotes.context: A candid moment tying real-life responsibilities to content strategy and creative compromise—high documentary relevance.

key_stories.title: F3DEX3 finally delivers major framerate headroom
key_stories.summary: Kaze shows that Sauraen’s F3DEX3 microcode is now functioning correctly in his build, immediately improving framerate in heavy scenes. This becomes the basis for a broader realization: once some classic bottlenecks are addressed, the limiting factor shifts, changing how the team should optimize the project.
key_stories.challenge: The level’s rendering cost and prior microcode behavior limited framerate, and earlier assumptions emphasized RDP/fillrate and memory traffic.
key_stories.process: Kaze integrates/tests F3DEX3, inspects performance live (including overdraw from faraway, invisible actors), and discusses tuning draw distance/culling and measurement overhead.
key_stories.outcome: The project appears capable of stable 60 FPS with further tuning, and Kaze reframes optimization priorities toward RSP limitations rather than defaulting to RDP blame.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe the world is just not ready to move on from blaming the RDP on the N64 and fillrate… one day they will optimize their RSP.

key_stories.title: Course 13 hits a collision-triangle memory wall
key_stories.summary: While detailing Course 13’s current state, Kaze reveals the level is temporarily out of collision triangle memory. Instead of stopping progress, he plans a stopgap approach until the collision system is replaced with a collision map.
key_stories.challenge: Collision triangle memory limits prevent adding/maintaining full interactable geometry in the current setup.
key_stories.process: Kaze explains the constraint, plans a future conversion to a collision map, and proposes temporarily making some geometry non-collidable/untouchable.
key_stories.outcome: Development can continue with temporary limitations; a future collision-map milestone is positioned as the real fix.
key_stories.key_quote: As soon as we make a collision map, that issue will go away.

key_stories.title: A mysterious ambient-light dropout near extra light sources
key_stories.summary: Kaze demonstrates a lighting bug where ambient light disappears as Mario approaches an additional light source. The behavior appears version/microcode dependent (works on X3, breaks in his emulator path using X2 under specific GeoLayout lighting), making it harder to diagnose.
key_stories.challenge: Ambient lighting vanishes near certain lights, harming the look/consistency of the level and suggesting an engine/render-pipeline edge case.
key_stories.process: He tests in different configurations (X3 vs emulator/X2) and narrows it to how lighting is applied (e.g., Mario’s GeoLayout involvement).
key_stories.outcome: Bug remains unresolved but is documented with hypotheses, becoming a concrete technical follow-up for later debugging.
key_stories.key_quote: It doesn't seem to be an emulator bug either.

key_stories.title: A contained Course 1 demo becomes the next public milestone
key_stories.summary: Rather than promising another broad demo, Kaze commits to a focused Course 1 demo showcasing systemic improvements (new camera and Mario controls). This frames a deliberate release strategy: ship a polished slice to validate feel and tech.
key_stories.challenge: A full-game demo may be impractical while major systems and courses are still in flux.
key_stories.process: Kaze outlines a Course 1-only demo scope and pairs it with planned YouTube videos explaining optimizations and the demo itself.
key_stories.outcome: A clear, achievable near-term deliverable that doubles as a marketing/feedback checkpoint.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm planning a demo of just Course 1.

key_stories.title: Parenthood increases production pressure and tempts “selling out”
key_stories.summary: Kaze connects his new family responsibilities to a more aggressive content plan and a fear of compromising creatively for income. It’s a rare moment where life logistics directly shape the project’s communication and possibly its development cadence.
key_stories.challenge: Needing more income after having a child while maintaining creative integrity and avoiding content trends he dislikes.
key_stories.process: He discusses increasing video output and weighing more commercial strategies, while explicitly rejecting becoming a drama-style creator.
key_stories.outcome: A stated intent to publish more, with unresolved tension about how far he’ll bend toward algorithm-friendly content.
key_stories.key_quote: Let's see how much I have to sell out.

open_questions.topic: F3DEX3 adoption plan and compatibility targets
open_questions.context: Kaze demonstrates strong gains with F3DEX3 but also references running X2 in emulator contexts and doubts about NSO emulation being good enough for the full game.
questions: What’s the decision point for making F3DEX3 the default for RTYI—will you ship separate builds, or fully transition the project?
What platforms are you treating as “must work” for release (real hardware, popular emulators, NSO), and how does microcode choice affect that?
What specific changes in F3DEX3 unlocked the performance increase you’re seeing in this level?

open_questions.topic: RSP-vs-memory bottleneck: what changed your mind?
open_questions.context: Kaze says the team was wrong about memory traffic being the main limiter and now believes RSP becomes the bottleneck after memory is optimized.
questions: What experiment or metric was the ‘aha moment’ that convinced you the RSP—not the RDP—was limiting performance?
Looking back, what optimizations gave the biggest returns before you hit the RSP wall?
How does this change what you ask collaborators to do (level design constraints, art budgets, culling strategy)?

open_questions.context: Course 13 is currently running out of memory for collision triangles, with a planned shift to a collision map as the real fix.
questions: What’s the technical approach for the collision map—will it be authored manually, generated from geometry, or a hybrid?
How does the temporary ‘make it untouchable’ workaround affect playtesting and level iteration right now?
Was this collision limit predictable earlier, or did the level’s complexity exceed your initial budgets?

open_questions.context: Ambient light vanishes near additional light sources; Kaze notes differing behavior between X3 and X2/emulator setups and possible GeoLayout involvement.
questions: What are your strongest hypotheses right now—state leakage, light count limits, a GeoLayout ordering issue, or something microcode-specific?
How do you test lighting issues across hardware/emulators without chasing phantom differences?
If the bug persists, would you redesign the lighting system (or authoring rules) to avoid the edge case?

open_questions.topic: Course 1 demo scope and success criteria
open_questions.context: Kaze plans a Course 1-only demo to showcase the new camera and Mario controls instead of a broader demo.
questions: What exactly must be ‘done’ for the Course 1 demo—camera features, control feel, difficulty tuning, visuals, performance targets?
How will you use feedback from this demo to adjust the rest of the game—especially the difficulty split you described?
Are you treating the Course 1 demo as a vertical slice for press/creators, or primarily as a systems test for core fans?
